questions.text: You are seeing a 5-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic with a 2-day history of redness and foreign body sensation in both eyes. She has not experienced vision loss. Her mother reports that, during this time, the child has had episodes of violent coughing followed by a high-pitched inspiratory sound. Over the past week, she has had low-grade fevers and a runny nose. Her only vaccinations were received at birth. Her temperature is 37.7°C. Examination reveals conjunctival hemorrhage and petechiae. Oropharyngeal examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Artificial tears are a treatment option for allergic conjunctivitis. Allergic conjunctivitis frequently manifests with itching, excessive tearing, sneezing, foreign body sensation, and potentially ptosis. However, this patient presents with bilateral conjunctival hemorrhage and petechiae due to pertussis infection, for which artificial tears are not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Although this patient presents with symptoms consistent with neisserial conjunctivitis (i.e., redness and foreign body sensation in both eyes), this condition would typically also cause unilateral thick purulent discharge and reduced vision. Furthermore, neisserial conjunctivitis is not associated with whooping cough. Intramuscular ceftriaxone is not used in the treatment of pertussis.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has pertussis due to an infection with Bordetella pertussis, which is a gram‑negative, aerobic bacillus. Aminoglycosides are generally effective against Bordetella species. However, antibiotic drops (e.g., topical tobramycin) are not an effective treatment for pertussis. Systemic tobramycin is also not a recommended treatment option because safer alternatives with fewer side effects are available.

D) CORRECT:

Macrolides such as azithromycin are the treatment of choice for pertussis. Early administration of macrolides can lessen symptoms in the catarrhal and paroxysmal stage. Late antibiotic administration has little influence on disease severity but does reduce infectivity. Therefore, oral azithromycin is indicated in this patient. Azithromycin is preferred over the other macrolides because it is easier to dose (once daily short course) and has a lower incidence of gastrointestinal adverse effects. Infants < 6 weeks of age who are being treated with azithromycin or erythromycin should be monitored for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which is a reported association.

Key learning point: Macrolide antibiotics such as azithromycin are the treatment of choice for pertussis, reducing symptoms if given early and decreasing infectivity even if started later.

E) INCORRECT:

Penicillin V is the treatment of choice for bacterial acute tonsillitis, which is most commonly due to infection with Streptococcus pyogenes. Patients with acute tonsillitis may also present with nasal discharge, fever, and cough but would not have high-pitched coughing spells or subconjunctival hemorrhage.
questions.hint: In a patient with an incomplete immunization record, signs of an upper respiratory infection (nasal discharge, low-grade fever) and intense paroxysmal coughing with a high-pitched “whooping” sound indicate pertussis (whooping cough). Severe coughing can lead to bilateral conjunctival hemorrhage and subsequent foreign body sensation in the eyes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of persistent, worsening dry cough and increasingly frequent severe coughing fits that sometimes lead to vomiting. He has not had any fevers or chills. He mentions that several coworkers recently had a “cold” but recovered quickly. He is up to date on his seasonal influenza and Covid-19 vaccinations. He has no history of lung disease. A chest radiograph shows mild lung hyperinflation but no acute cardiopulmonary process. Which one of the following tests is indicated for this patient?

choices.text: Polymerase chain-reaction testing and culture of a nasopharyngeal aspirate or swab for Bordetella pertussis.
Cell culture of nasopharyngeal swab for adenovirus.
Polymerase chain-reaction testing of a nasal swab for respiratory syncytial virus.
Gram stain and bacterial culture of sputum.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma cannot be readily cultured in microbiology laboratories and hence would require either PCR or serologic testing.

B) CORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis infection is frequently missed in adults because they often present without a true whooping cough and because many clinicians perceive it as a childhood disease. However, it is a relatively common cause of persistent severe cough in adults, and diagnosis is important for limiting the spread of infection. Immunity following acellular pertussis vaccination may begin to decline after 4 to 5 years, making many adults susceptible to B. pertussis. B. pertussis infection is characterized by respiratory illness of 2 to 3 weeks; its predominant symptom is catarrhal cough, sometimes accompanied by post-tussive emesis. In certain individuals, the cough may persist for months.

B. pertussis is not grown easily in a clinical microbiology setting, so polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) testing or selective agars should be performed when B. pertussis is suspected. In the first 4 weeks of symptoms, PCR and culture are both recommended; after 4 weeks, recovery of the organism by either method is unlikely, and serologic testing is recommended.

Key learning point: An adult who has a persistent cough with severe coughing fits and vomiting should be evaluated for infection caused by Bordetella pertussis.

C) INCORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus and adenovirus infections can cause acute upper, and sometimes lower, respiratory tract symptoms and can also lead to chronic symptoms by damaging the respiratory epithelium and causing chronic bronchitis. However, worsening cough and episodic coughing fits are not characteristic of post-viral bronchitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus and adenovirus infections can cause acute upper, and sometimes lower, respiratory tract symptoms and can also lead to chronic symptoms by damaging the respiratory epithelium and causing chronic bronchitis. However, the worsening course of symptoms, leading to vomiting, is suggestive of a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Gram stain and bacterial culture of sputum has limited utility in prolonged cough, particularly if the chest radiograph does not reveal an acute process; it is most likely to be helpful early in an illness characterized by increased respiratory secretions, especially in those with chronic lung disease.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with a 9-day history of rhinorrhea and low-grade fever that has progressed to intense coughing episodes and apneic spells. The patient's mother declined any vaccination during pregnancy. Vital signs are BP, 120/70; P, 145; R, 35; T, 37.4°C (99.3°F); oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation
Admit for observation, send blood cultures, and start pathogen-specific treatment based on result
Start azithromycin and arrange hospital admission
Administer nebulized albuterol and reassess respiratory status
Obtain nasopharyngeal PCR and discharge with close follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are not recommended for treating pertussis as there is no evidence that they reduce cough duration or severity. Another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are not recommended because of low specificity and sensitivity, and antibiotic therapy should be started immediately without waiting for diagnostic confirmation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This infant has paroxysmal cough and apnea, which meets the case definition for suspected pertussis. Antibiotic therapy should be started immediately without waiting for diagnostic confirmation, and admission is indicated because of the patient's apneic episodes.

D) INCORRECT:

Nebulized albuterol is effective for treating bronchospasm but not for pertussis. This patient presents with paroxysmal coughing and apneic episodes, which are characteristic of pertussis, and symptomatic treatments are not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

While nasopharyngeal PCR is appropriate for diagnosing pertussis, this infant presents with apneic episodes, and the mother was not immunized during pregnancy, which meets the admission criteria for the condition. Discharge is inappropriate given the high risk of complications.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a 5-week history of paroxysmal coughing episodes with posttussive vomiting. The patient's mother reports that the child has received all recommended vaccinations per the routine schedule but attends a day care with many unvaccinated children. Physical examination shows mild conjunctival petechiae and no fever. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 18,000/μL with 65% lymphocytes. What is the most appropriate confirmatory test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Culture has limited sensitivity, particularly in vaccinated patients, and becomes increasingly unreliable after 4 weeks of symptoms because of decreased bacterial shedding. The long growth time also delays diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

While lymphocytosis raises suspicion for pertussis, repeating the complete blood count will not confirm the diagnosis because elevated lymphocyte count is a supportive rather than diagnostic finding.

C) INCORRECT:

PCR is the preferred test for patients with suspected pertussis who are within 1–4 weeks of symptom onset. At 5 weeks, PCR sensitivity decreases significantly as bacterial shedding declines, making it less reliable for diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Direct fluorescent antibody testing is not recommended for pertussis diagnosis because it has low specificity and sensitivity regardless of symptom duration or patient characteristics.

E) CORRECT:

Correct — Serology is appropriate 4–12 weeks after symptom onset in patients with suspected pertussis who are ≥ 6 months of age and ≥ 1 year since last vaccination. This 3-year-old patient has had symptoms for 5 weeks, and their last DTaP given 15–18 months ago, which meets all criteria for serologic testing.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with a 7-day history of intermittent cough and feeding difficulties. The parents report episodes of breathing cessation lasting 10–15 seconds during coughing fits. The infant was born at 35 weeks' gestation. Physical examination shows mild nasal congestion and a benign chest examination. PCR testing confirms Bordetella pertussis. The infant requires admission for monitoring. What is the most appropriate immediate infection control measure?

choices.text: Contact precautions with gown and gloves

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Standard precautions alone are insufficient for pertussis.

B) INCORRECT:

Contact precautions are used for pathogens transmitted through direct contact or contaminated surfaces. While B. pertussis can survive on fomites, respiratory droplets are the primary mode of transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

Airborne precautions with N95 respirators are reserved for airborne pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis or the measles virus. B. pertussis transmission occurs through larger respiratory droplets, not airborne particles.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Pertussis spreads primarily through respiratory droplets generated during coughing episodes. Droplet precautions with surgical mask protection are the most appropriate infection control measure. Patients should be placed in a single room.

E) INCORRECT:

Reverse isolation protects immunocompromised patients from acquiring infections, but this patient is not immunocompromised and is already infected. The most appropriate infection control measure is preventing the spread of pertussis to others.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department for severe coughing spells. The parents report that during these episodes, the infant's face turns blue and he occasionally vomits. The infant is partially immunized. Examination shows bilateral subconjunctival hemorrhages. During an observed paroxysm, the infant becomes apneic and has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. This patient's neurologic complication is most likely a direct result of which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Post-infectious autoimmune phenomena, such as acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), can cause seizures. However, these conditions typically develop days to weeks after the acute infection has begun to resolve. The seizure in this infant occurred acutely during a coughing paroxysm, making a different mechanism a much more direct and plausible cause than a delayed autoimmune process.

B) CORRECT:

The characteristic paroxysmal coughing spells in severe pertussis are so intense that they interfere with ventilation and gas exchange, leading to hypoxemia. The clinical signs of this are cyanosis (ie, the infant's face turns blue) and apnea. Cerebral hypoxia is a direct consequence of this severe oxygen deprivation. The infant brain is highly vulnerable to hypoxic injury, which can manifest as encephalopathy and seizures. The seizure occurring during an apneic episode strongly supports hypoxia as the underlying mechanism. Other complications from the forceful coughing include subconjunctival hemorrhages and post-tussive emesis.

C) INCORRECT:

While some bacterial infections cause neurologic symptoms through direct neurotoxins, this is not the primary mechanism for seizures in pertussis. The toxins produced by Bordetella pertussis primarily target the respiratory epithelium and immune cells, leading to the characteristic severe cough. The neurologic complications in this patient are most likely due to a different mechanism rather than a direct toxic effect on the central nervous system.

D) INCORRECT:

Meningitis can cause seizures in an infant. However, this patient's clinical picture is dominated by severe respiratory symptoms. There are no specific signs of meningitis mentioned, such as fever, lethargy, or a bulging fontanelle. The seizure is temporally associated with a coughing paroxysm and apnea, making a respiratory cause more likely than a separate infectious process like meningitis.
questions.hint: This infant's presentation of paroxysmal coughing, post-tussive emesis, and cyanosis suggests pertussis (whooping cough).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of low-grade fevers and a cough lasting for 2 weeks. He has vomited several times after fits of coughing. He has no history of serious illness and has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F). Physical examination shows erythema of the nasal and oral mucosa. While in the exam room, he has a long series of consecutive coughs, during which he appears diaphoretic. The coughing is followed by a loud inspiratory gasp. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 16,300/mm3 (67% lymphocytes). The pathogen most likely responsible for this patient's presentation contains a toxin that acts by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pertussis toxin is an important virulence factor of Bordetella pertussis. This AB exotoxin binds to the surface of host cells and enters them by endocytosis. Inside the cytosol, pertussis toxin catalyzes the ADP-ribosylation of the α subunit of Gi proteins, which prevents their interaction with G protein-coupled receptors and thus impairs inhibition of adenylate cyclase activity. The resultant accumulation of cAMP disrupts cellular signaling pathways and causes various pathological effects in host cells. This includes the modulation of the host immune response, e.g., the inhibition of neutrophil migration. Pertussis toxin also causes several systemic manifestations associated with whooping cough, such as lymphocytosis.

See “Overview of exotoxins” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevation of intracellular cGMP via the overactivation of guanylate cyclase is the action mechanism of heat-stable toxins produced by enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). The elevation inhibits the reabsorption of salt and water by enterocytes, leading to watery diarrhea. However, it does not produce respiratory symptoms as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The inactivation of host cells' elongation factor 2 (EF-2) via ADP-ribosylation is the action mechanism of both exotoxin A, which is produced by P. aeruginosa, and diphtheria toxin, which is secreted by C. diphtheriae. These exotoxins inhibit protein translation and result in cell death and necrosis. Although this patient presents with fever and cough, other symptoms of diphtheria (e.g., a grayish pharyngeal and tonsillar pseudomembrane, bull neck due to cervical lymphadenopathy, and myocarditis) are not present, which makes this diagnosis unlikely. Without prior hospitalization and no sign of pneumonia (e.g., crackles on auscultation, malaise, high fever, and chills), nosocomial pneumonia caused by P. aeruginosa is also unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

The inactivation of the 60S subunit in host cells' ribosomes is the action mechanism of Shiga toxin (produced by Shigella) and Shiga-like toxin (produced by enterohemorrhagic E. coli; EHEC). Both of these cleave adenine in rRNA (ribosomal RNA), which causes enterocyte damage and bloody diarrhea. Neither Shigella nor E. coli cause respiratory symptoms like those seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis produces several virulence factors that promote adhesion to cells, local tissue damage, and the impairment of phagocytosis. However, none of its exotoxins induce the activation of Gi-coupled protein receptors.
questions.hint: In an unvaccinated child, the symptoms of low-grade fever, intense paroxysms of cough followed by inspiratory stridor (“whoop”), posttussive emesis, and lymphocytosis are highly suggestive of whooping cough, an infection caused by Bordetella pertussis.
